        Social Scene

        1. Social Scene | Community Builders: Laugh for the Cure

          The Ottawa Cancer Foundation aimed to prove the adage that laughter is the best medicine by hosting Laugh for the Cure at the Shaw Centre on Tuesday, March 26. Five local business leaders teamed up with professional comedians, pooling their wit and humour to raise funds. Brent Butt, renowned for his role in Corner Gas, headlined the night with his uproarious entertainment. Together, the Joes and the Pros crafted comedic routines to tickle the audience’s funny bones while supporting supportive cancer care. The event embodied a unique blend of laughter and philanthropy, uniting the community in a shared mission of hope and healing.

          5 days ago Social Scene
          Sponsored by STAR MOTORS OF OTTAWA

          You can save this article by registering for free here. Or sign-in if you have an account.

        2. Social Scene | Community Builders: Visionaries Breakfast

          Close to 300 guests gathered Wednesday, March 27, at the Brookstreet Hotel with a sense of purpose that swirled with the aroma of fresh coffee at the Queensway Carleton Hospital Foundation’s Visionaries Breakfast. The celebration honoured the remarkable legacy of the late Shirley and Irving Greenberg who were recognized with the QCH Foundation’s Visionary Award. Instead of vying for material treasures, guests raised their auction paddles to secure vital tools for patient care. From bladder scanners to bedside cardiac monitors, each donation represented a lifeline for those in need. The early morning event brought in $515,238, which will be put to work to fund the purchase of life-saving medical devices and equipment.

          5 days ago Social Scene
          Sponsored by STAR MOTORS OF OTTAWA

          You can save this article by registering for free here. Or sign-in if you have an account.

        4. Social Scene | Community Builders: Senators Black, Red & Gold Gala

          On Monday, March 25, the Canadian Tire Centre was transformed from a hockey arena into a glamorous space that hosted 550 guests for the sold-out CIBC Senators Black, Red & Gold Gala. The spectacular event evolved from Sens Soirée, and will continue its legacy of providing underserved children with the opportunities they need to fulfil their potential. Over $650,000 was raised to help support children and youth in our community.  “We want you to remember that tonight you put food in someone’s belly, a hockey stick in a child’s hand, and provided a shoulder to cry on,” said Jacqueline Belsito, president of the Senators Community Foundation, as she took to the stage to wrap up the formal portion of the evening. “You helped create a number of spaces that are safe and welcoming so that children and youth can walk in them, without fear.” If you know of someone doing something exceptional to help, we would love to share their story. Please send details to socialscene@postmedia.com and we will be in touch.

          March 26, 2024 Social Scene
          Sponsored by STAR MOTORS OF OTTAWA

          You can save this article by registering for free here. Or sign-in if you have an account.

        5. Social Scene | Community Builders: CN Cycle for CHEO

          Griffin Bell: June 26, 2017 – March 18, 2024 With a heavy heart, I need to report that since photographing this superhero late last week, he has closed his eyes one last time. “This little hero is now fighting in the sky,” his mother Tamy Bell said over a text message Monday after her son, six-year-old Griffin Bell, passed away that morning. “I want to talk about him forever,” Bell said, as she gave her approval to go ahead with this feature. “He amazes me every day. His strength and determination are amazing,” Bell said last week. “Sadly, for children with relapsed neuroblastoma, which we have been dealing with for three solid years now, there is no protocol. It is very much a trial-and-error process. We have been trying, but it hasn’t been working. Unfortunately, the devastating reality is that there is no known fix for this, which is why events like the CN Cycle are so incredibly important to us. Pediatric cancer needs more funding for research.” For the Bell family, CN Cycle for CHEO is all about people coming together to support families like theirs. What Bell describes as the best day of the year, the 17th annual event is slated to take place Sunday, May 5, to raise money for CHEO’s clinicians and researchers to make progress in delivering life-saving cancer care. CN Cycle for CHEO has something for everyone to take part in, from 70k, 35k, or 15k cycling options to 5k and 2k walks. The special day is going to be the Bell family’s biggest year yet, in honour of Griff. The family partners with local businesses to sponsor Griff’s Super Family Fun Zone, and last year their team raised over $108,000. This year there are already 70 members on their team and fundraising is off to a good start. “The kindness and generosity of this community is amazing,” Bell said. Griffin, a courageous warrior battling cancer, stood as a beacon of strength for many. The little entertainer I introduced Social Scene readers to in 2021 started his cancer battle two years earlier, and was a regular in the halls of CHEO. He underwent endless sessions of chemotherapy, radiation, medical trials and adventures to other children’s hospitals for more treatments. Between all the medical treatments and his time in hospitals, Griff never stopped being a positive ray of light with his mischievous little smile. “The pediatric oncology world is a cruel, unfair one,” said Bell. “If we can play a small part in changing its future, then that is our reason to keep on going, to participate in an event like this.” For more information and to register for CN Cycle for CHEO, head to www.cncycle.ca, or visit the Griff’s Gang fundraising page to show support for this important cause. With camaraderie of community and hope for tomorrow, the Bell family is wishful for a brighter, cancer-free future for all. If you know of someone doing something exceptional to help, we would love to share their story. Please send details to socialscene@postmedia.com and we will be in touch.

          March 18, 2024 Social Scene
          Sponsored by STAR MOTORS OF OTTAWA

          You can save this article by registering for free here. Or sign-in if you have an account.

        6. Social Scene | Community Builders: The Power Lunch, Room at the Table

          Friday, March 8, marked a momentous occasion as women across the globe united in celebration of International Women’s Day — a time to spotlight the remarkable social, economic, cultural and political accomplishments of women. In Ottawa, the National Arts Centre took centre stage as the destination for The Power Lunch: Room at the Table. The event, orchestrated under the guidance of Catherine Landry, the driving force behind She Shops Local, showcased  local businesses. Event host Lucy van Oldenbarneveld was joined onstage by honoured guests for an engaging and insightful open dialogue.

          March 11, 2024 Social Scene
          Sponsored by STAR MOTORS OF OTTAWA

          You can save this article by registering for free here. Or sign-in if you have an account.
